The conversation we should be having is about Inclusion. For a few years we've been talking about DEI mostly in terms of Diversity. Don't get me wrong--My belief is that organizations should reflect at all levels their customer base--but to focus only on Diversity is a mistake and I honestly think we should be looking at Inclusion first--or at least leaders should. Often we think of inclusion as a sentiment. How our employees feel...and to a certain extent it is that. Do ALL employees feel that their voice is heard? Do ALL employees feel that they are celebrated for their unique perspectives? Do All employees feel valued for what they bring to the table? Do all employees feel invited to the table? You get the idea. Inclusion temperature can of course be looked at with employee surveys. But there are other ways you can measure inclusion in your organization. Ways that might give you better insight into what is really happening. Open invite to join the November Allied Industry Inclusion Council where we will talk about Inclusion and Ways You Can MEASURE it. Diversity and inclusion in the workplace go beyond hiring diverse talent; it extends to our external partnerships and collaborations. True diversity and inclusion make a company not only diverse within but also connected to the world outside. Internally, inclusion fosters a vibrant organizational culture, leveraging diverse perspectives, and enabling us to tap into new markets and engage in versatile forms of communication and representation. Inclusion and diversity thus demand our active engagement in vendor management, supply chains, and partnerships. Embracing diversity and inclusion isn't just about improving culture; it's a potent catalyst for positive change. Yesterday, I had a great conversation with Sonali Anderson, who was a fellow awardee at this year‚Äôs New England Women in Energy and the Environment (NEWIEE) Gala. It seems like every organization is touting their climate and DEI credentials lately, and we talked about how to determine whether companies are truly walking the talk. Here are two of the main points from our conversation: First, assess the company‚Äôs key performance indicators: What metrics and outcomes are they working toward? Is GHG reduction their main goal? Or financial growth? Do they have company-wide equity goals for both how they operate and the impact they generate? If so, how are they tracking on those? Knowing the answers to these questions tells you what is really at the heart of the organization and what will drive their decision making. Second, assess the company‚Äôs culture: What is their employee net promoter score and how has it changed over the past few years? How long have they been working on DEI? How are they putting their DEI commitments into practice? Do they have a DEI committee, culture committee, or employee resource groups to support their team members? What‚Äôs the average tenure of their staff and what percentage of employees are promoted into new roles annually? Having these answers tells you what it's like to work at--or work with--an organization and how they operate day to day. I'm happy to say VEIC has great answers to all of these questions and I'm proud of the work that we have done as an organization to get where we are today. There's still a lot of work to do, but we're on the right path. Thanks to NEWIEE for bringing us together and sparking a great conversation!
